content.name: array
content.title: Array
content.details:
A sequence of values.

You can construct an array by enclosing a comma-separated sequence of values in parentheses. The values do not have to be of the same type.

You can access and update array items with the .at() method. Indices are zero-based and negative indices wrap around to the end of the array. You can iterate over an array using a for loop. Arrays can be added together with the + operator, joined together and multiplied with integers.

Note: An array of length one needs a trailing comma, as in (1,). This is to disambiguate from a simple parenthesized expressions like (1 + 2) * 3. An empty array is written as ().

Example

#let values = (1, 7, 4, -3, 2)

#values.at(0) \
#(values.at(0) = 3)
#values.at(-1) \
#values.find(calc.even) \
#values.filter(calc.odd) \
#values.map(calc.abs) \
#values.rev() \
#(1, (2, 3)).flatten() \
#(("A", "B", "C")
    .join(", ", last: " and "))

constructor.name: array
constructor.title: Construct
constructor.oneliner: Converts a value to an array.
constructor.details:
Converts a value to an array.

Note that this function is only intended for conversion of a collection-like value to an array, not for creation of an array from individual items. Use the array syntax (1, 2, 3) (or (1,) for a single-element array) instead.
constructor.example:
#let hi = "Hello üòÉ"
#array(bytes(hi))

params.name: value
params.details: The value that should be converted to an array.

scope.name: len
scope.title: Length
scope.oneliner: The number of values in the array.
scope.details: The number of values in the array.

scope.name: first
scope.title: First
scope.oneliner: Returns the first item in the array. May be used on the left-hand side
scope.details: Returns the first item in the array. May be used on the left-hand side of an assignment. Fails with an error if the array is empty.

scope.name: last
scope.title: Last
scope.oneliner: Returns the last item in the array. May be used on the left-hand side of
scope.details: Returns the last item in the array. May be used on the left-hand side of an assignment. Fails with an error if the array is empty.

scope.name: at
scope.title: At
scope.oneliner: Returns the item at the specified index in the array. May be used on the
scope.details: Returns the item at the specified index in the array. May be used on the left-hand side of an assignment. Returns the default value if the index is out of bounds or fails with an error if no default value was specified.

params.name: index
params.details: The index at which to retrieve the item. If negative, indexes from the back.

params.name: default
params.details: A default value to return if the index is out of bounds.

scope.name: push
scope.title: Push
scope.oneliner: Adds a value to the end of the array.
scope.details: Adds a value to the end of the array.

params.name: value
params.details: The value to insert at the end of the array.

scope.name: pop
scope.title: Pop
scope.oneliner: Removes the last item from the array and returns it. Fails with an error
scope.details: Removes the last item from the array and returns it. Fails with an error if the array is empty.

scope.name: insert
scope.title: Insert
scope.oneliner: Inserts a value into the array at the specified index, shifting all
scope.details:
Inserts a value into the array at the specified index, shifting all subsequent elements to the right. Fails with an error if the index is out of bounds.

To replace an element of an array, use at.

params.name: index
params.details: The index at which to insert the item. If negative, indexes from the back.

params.name: value
params.details: The value to insert into the array.

scope.name: remove
scope.title: Remove
scope.oneliner: Removes the value at the specified index from the array and return it.
scope.details: Removes the value at the specified index from the array and return it.

params.name: index
params.details: The index at which to remove the item. If negative, indexes from the back.

params.name: default
params.details: A default value to return if the index is out of bounds.

scope.name: slice
scope.title: Slice
scope.oneliner: Extracts a subslice of the array. Fails with an error if the start or end
scope.details: Extracts a subslice of the array. Fails with an error if the start or end index is out of bounds.

params.name: start
params.details: The start index (inclusive). If negative, indexes from the back.

params.name: end
params.details: The end index (exclusive). If omitted, the whole slice until the end of the array is extracted. If negative, indexes from the back.

params.name: count
params.details: The number of items to extract. This is equivalent to passing start + count as the end position. Mutually exclusive with end.

scope.name: contains
scope.title: Contains
scope.oneliner: Whether the array contains the specified value.
scope.details:
Whether the array contains the specified value.

This method also has dedicated syntax: You can write 2 in (1, 2, 3) instead of (1, 2, 3).contains(2).

params.name: value
params.details: The value to search for.

scope.name: find
scope.title: Find
scope.oneliner: Searches for an item for which the given function returns `{true}` and
scope.details: Searches for an item for which the given function returns true and returns the first match or none if there is no match.

params.name: searcher
params.details: The function to apply to each item. Must return a boolean.

scope.name: position
scope.title: Position
scope.oneliner: Searches for an item for which the given function returns `{true}` and
scope.details: Searches for an item for which the given function returns true and returns the index of the first match or none if there is no match.

params.name: searcher
params.details: The function to apply to each item. Must return a boolean.

scope.name: range
scope.title: Range
scope.oneliner: Create an array consisting of a sequence of numbers.
scope.details:
Create an array consisting of a sequence of numbers.

If you pass just one positional parameter, it is interpreted as the end of the range. If you pass two, they describe the start and end of the range.

This function is available both in the array function's scope and globally.
scope.example:
#range(5) \
#range(2, 5) \
#range(20, step: 4) \
#range(21, step: 4) \
#range(5, 2, step: -1)

params.name: start
params.details: The start of the range (inclusive).

params.name: end
params.details: The end of the range (exclusive).

params.name: step
params.details: The distance between the generated numbers.

scope.name: filter
scope.title: Filter
scope.oneliner: Produces a new array with only the items from the original one for which
scope.details: Produces a new array with only the items from the original one for which the given function returns true.

params.name: test
params.details: The function to apply to each item. Must return a boolean.

scope.name: map
scope.title: Map
scope.oneliner: Produces a new array in which all items from the original one were
scope.details: Produces a new array in which all items from the original one were transformed with the given function.

params.name: mapper
params.details: The function to apply to each item.

scope.name: enumerate
scope.title: Enumerate
scope.oneliner: Returns a new array with the values alongside their indices.
scope.details:
Returns a new array with the values alongside their indices.

The returned array consists of (index, value) pairs in the form of length-2 arrays. These can be destructured with a let binding or for loop.

params.name: start
params.details: The index returned for the first pair of the returned list.

scope.name: zip
scope.title: Zip
scope.oneliner: Zips the array with other arrays.
scope.details:
Zips the array with other arrays.

Returns an array of arrays, where the ith inner array contains all the ith elements from each original array.

If the arrays to be zipped have different lengths, they are zipped up to the last element of the shortest array and all remaining elements are ignored.

This function is variadic, meaning that you can zip multiple arrays together at once: (1, 2).zip(("A", "B"), (10, 20)) yields ((1, "A", 10), (2, "B", 20)).

params.name: exact
params.details: Whether all arrays have to have the same length. For example, (1, 2).zip((1, 2, 3), exact: true) produces an error.

params.name: others
params.details: The arrays to zip with.

scope.name: fold
scope.title: Fold
scope.oneliner: Folds all items into a single value using an accumulator function.
scope.details: Folds all items into a single value using an accumulator function.

params.name: init
params.details: The initial value to start with.

params.name: folder
params.details: The folding function. Must have two parameters: One for the accumulated value and one for an item.

scope.name: sum
scope.title: Sum
scope.oneliner: Sums all items (works for all types that can be added).
scope.details: Sums all items (works for all types that can be added).

params.name: default
params.details: What to return if the array is empty. Must be set if the array can be empty.

scope.name: product
scope.title: Product
scope.oneliner: Calculates the product all items (works for all types that can be
scope.details: Calculates the product all items (works for all types that can be multiplied).

params.name: default
params.details: What to return if the array is empty. Must be set if the array can be empty.

scope.name: any
scope.title: Any
scope.oneliner: Whether the given function returns `{true}` for any item in the array.
scope.details: Whether the given function returns true for any item in the array.

params.name: test
params.details: The function to apply to each item. Must return a boolean.

scope.name: all
scope.title: All
scope.oneliner: Whether the given function returns `{true}` for all items in the array.
scope.details: Whether the given function returns true for all items in the array.

params.name: test
params.details: The function to apply to each item. Must return a boolean.

scope.name: flatten
scope.title: Flatten
scope.oneliner: Combine all nested arrays into a single flat one.
scope.details: Combine all nested arrays into a single flat one.

scope.name: rev
scope.title: Reverse
scope.oneliner: Return a new array with the same items, but in reverse order.
scope.details: Return a new array with the same items, but in reverse order.

scope.name: split
scope.title: Split
scope.oneliner: Split the array at occurrences of the specified value.
scope.details: Split the array at occurrences of the specified value.

params.name: at
params.details: The value to split at.

scope.name: join
scope.title: Join
scope.oneliner: Combine all items in the array into one.
scope.details: Combine all items in the array into one.

params.name: separator
params.details: A value to insert between each item of the array.

params.name: last
params.details: An alternative separator between the last two items.

scope.name: intersperse
scope.title: Intersperse
scope.oneliner: Returns an array with a copy of the separator value placed between
scope.details: Returns an array with a copy of the separator value placed between adjacent elements.

params.name: separator
params.details: The value that will be placed between each adjacent element.

scope.name: chunks
scope.title: Chunks
scope.oneliner: Splits an array into non-overlapping chunks, starting at the beginning,
scope.details:
Splits an array into non-overlapping chunks, starting at the beginning, ending with a single remainder chunk.

All chunks but the last have chunk-size elements. If exact is set to true, the remainder is dropped if it contains less than chunk-size elements.
scope.example:
#let array = (1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8)
#array.chunks(3) \
#array.chunks(3, exact: true)

params.name: chunk-size
params.details: How many elements each chunk may at most contain.

params.name: exact
params.details: Whether to keep the remainder if its size is less than chunk-size.

scope.name: windows
scope.title: Windows
scope.oneliner: Returns sliding windows of `window-size` elements over an array.
scope.details:
Returns sliding windows of window-size elements over an array.

If the array length is less than window-size, this will return an empty array.
scope.example:
#let array = (1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8)
#array.windows(5)

params.name: window-size
params.details: How many elements each window will contain.

scope.name: sorted
scope.title: Sorted
scope.oneliner: Return a sorted version of this array, optionally by a given key
scope.details:
Return a sorted version of this array, optionally by a given key function. The sorting algorithm used is stable.

Returns an error if two values could not be compared or if the key function (if given) yields an error.

To sort according to multiple criteria at once, e.g. in case of equality between some criteria, the key function can return an array. The results are in lexicographic order.
scope.example:
#let array = (
  (a: 2, b: 4),
  (a: 1, b: 5),
  (a: 2, b: 3),
)
#array.sorted(key: it => (it.a, it.b))

params.name: key
params.details: If given, applies this function to the elements in the array to determine the keys to sort by.

scope.name: dedup
scope.title: Deduplicate
scope.oneliner: Deduplicates all items in the array.
scope.details:
Deduplicates all items in the array.

Returns a new array with all duplicate items removed. Only the first element of each duplicate is kept.
scope.example: #(1, 1, 2, 3, 1).dedup()

params.name: key
params.details: If given, applies this function to the elements in the array to determine the keys to deduplicate by.

scope.name: to-dict
scope.title: To Dict
scope.oneliner: Converts an array of pairs into a dictionary.
scope.details:
Converts an array of pairs into a dictionary. The first value of each pair is the key, the second the value.

If the same key occurs multiple times, the last value is selected.
scope.example:
#(
  ("apples", 2),
  ("peaches", 3),
  ("apples", 5),
).to-dict()

scope.name: reduce
scope.title: Reduce
scope.oneliner: Reduces the elements to a single one, by repeatedly applying a reducing
scope.details:
Reduces the elements to a single one, by repeatedly applying a reducing operation.

If the array is empty, returns none, otherwise, returns the result of the reduction.

The reducing function is a closure with two arguments: an "accumulator", and an element.

For arrays with at least one element, this is the same as array.fold with the first element of the array as the initial accumulator value, folding every subsequent element into it.

params.name: reducer
params.details: The reducing function. Must have two parameters: One for the accumulated value and one for an item.
